page.title: 13Communication in the Cowtons
page.content: Until 1979 mail for each village was delivered to the local Post Offices, sorted there, and delivered by local postmen & women. The mail is now sorted at Northallerton and delivered to each house by a postman in a van. There is one delivery per day. Out- going mail is collected twice per day. The overall postmark is 'Darlington'. Approx. 70% of the population have their own telephone. There is an un- manned exchange at Cowton crossroads, with 500 numbers in the 'North Cowton' exchange. Operator calls and long dis- tance go through the Darlington exchange. There are three public tele- phone boxes, one in each main village and at Atley Hill. There are notice boards in all villages and local news letters are delivered to all houses. The village shops sell newspapers, and a free paper/advertiser is delivered.
